The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. Other well known examples are the lion/tiger hybrid, the liger, which is by far the largest big cat and sometimes used in circuses; and cattle hybrids such as between European and Indian domestic

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. This has caused minor controversy, but is largely recognized as not lending the school any significant advantage, since players receive no athletic and little physical training during their missions. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. This winter precipitation maximum is quite unusual for humid continental climates, which most commonly have a late spring or early summer precipitation maximum (for example, most of the Midwestern U.S.). The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The Bush administration then turned its attention to Iraq, and argued the need to remove Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq had become urgent. Among the stated reasons were that Iraq was believed to have weapons of mass destruction, had been involved in a scheme to assassinate the former UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan, was engaged in support for terrorism, and posed a threat to U.S., Israeli and other regional interests.

However, as we explained in our book ‘The Iraq War: A History‘, none of those allegations about Iraq’s WMD were true. Moreover, the only ‘evidence’ of the latter two allegations did not lead to investigations or charges in domestic courts. As for the other claims, there is no evidence that Saddam intended to kill Annan to frame him and then assassinate him. An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that the environment in which we live is different for everyone based on, among other things, socio-economic class, access to the arts, parental education levels, family size and family structure. However, there is a gap in the body of research about what adolescents think of themselves. The question that drives this study is: which identities do Latino adolescents identify with? In order to answer this question, a content analysis was performed on the self-generated descriptions of five Latino adolescents in the United States. This paper explores the characteristics of the self-identified identities the children expressed, and then describes how these results differ between children and their mothers, mothers and their children, and siblings. The participants' stories illustrate the influence of the socio-economic and educational environment on the way the children describe themselves. Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two in the U.S., and two at a neutral site location.

Most teams have just one pre-season game per year, usually against a team from the same division. So, teams in the playoffs or trying to make the Super Bowl face a different team from every division, and face five divisional teams, including three divisional opponents twice.

Intense media interest in the opinions and private lives of the royal family during the 1980s led to a series of sensational stories in the press, not least the infamous front-page headline in the Daily Mail on the day Diana married Charles in 1981: "We Think Princess Diana Has 'Fetish'" (24 May 1981). This episode shows how tabloid reporting on public figures and celebrities was often less objective than might be expected and how royal stories generated public interest in the same way as any celebrity or high-profile public figure would do.

The British press has been well-known for its focus on celebrities of various kinds for many decades, and for this genre of public interest coverage, the public became interested in the royal family over the 1990s (for a detailed analysis, see Hall and Clarke). The press followed up on various rumours and speculations published in both popular and specialist magazines about the princes and princesses, and this generated large volumes of press coverage.

To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in southern Manchuria, finally defeating their general Dorjiev in the Battle of Aldan in 1727. The Dzungar Khanate was fully integrated into the Qing Empire, and the last Dzungar king, Dorjiev Khan, was made a Manchu bannerman. The Dzungar Khanate remained a vassal to the Qing Empire for the vast majority of its existence. The Kangxi Emperor was the last emperor to personally lead an army into Manchuria. From that point onward, military campaigns in the region were handled by the Manchu Imperial Guard.

From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and others, on the cultural dynamics of subalterns has been influential on cultural studies. And from the 1990s and 2000s, Hall's theorization of "postmodernity" has been influential in the study of postmodernity among English and US theorists of art, culture, and social change, such as Fredric Jameson, Lisa Appignanesi, and Steven Wright.

Hall was born in England in 1938 and was educated at the University of York. From 1968 to 1976 he was Chairman of the Department of English at the University of Birmingham, and from 1976 to 1998 he was Director of the school of English at Essex University. In 2003 he was awarded an honorary doctorate from Birmingham. He died in 2010, aged 68.

Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. This variation in color can be seen on humans and most mammals. Human hair exhibits a degree of color variation. The color of a person changes, varying from person to person, and possibly varying from time to time. The different colors of human hair can be described as a color spectrum.

Hair color can also vary from one individual of a species to another or from one population of a species to another. For example, in domestic animals, some breeds have a common skin color and are often grey, and some breeds have specific body-color/fur patterns for reasons of protection from the elements and/or sexual selection. Hair color can also vary within an individual of a species, between the different parts of the skin, and between the genders of a species.

But in the mid-18th century, during the French Enlightenment, a more ideological use of the term had come into use. This is a somewhat loose use of the term _nature_ that is more than simply utilitarian, and it is precisely in this usage that the term has come to have, in the English-speaking world, a positive connotation as a synonym of nature, rather than merely describing the natural world."

More commonly, in cases where there are three or more parties, no one party is likely to gain power alone, and parties work with each other to form alliances to maximize their chance of winning (often relying on the electoral law to do so). In such situations there is a need for political calculus over who should be allied against whom to ensure maximum advantage for both parties, and this has led to a number of alliances between parties which have little apparent public support.

A classic case of this is the electoral pact between the French Socialists and The Radicals in 1978, who agreed that the Socialists would not stand in the presidential and parliamentary elections and would leave the French Communist Party leader, François Mitterrand, free to take power alone on 21 April 1979. This was seen, understandably, by some as a betrayal of socialist principles, and some parties broke away from Mitterrand's UDF and formed the Alliance of Democrats (Alliance démocratique) to contest the general election

Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology, particularly with the stress systems. This is important because emotions are related to several health problems including stress, pain, eating disorders, depression, and substance abuse. These emotional responses contribute to an individual's response to the environment and may increase the likelihood of certain choices or decrease the probability of another. Emotional reactions can also affect an individual's response to health related issues. For example, people who are often angry or have anger issues may lack the ability to successfully manage anger or control themselves and subsequently may develop physical symptoms when they are angry, especially with regard to the pancreas, spleen, thyroid, stomach, and kidneys. However, not a lot is known about the neural circuitry underlying emotion and physiological responses.

The identity approach to psychology was originally developed in an effort to address the limitations of the more classical models of personality. It is a major shift in the conceptualization and explanation of psychological processes from the classical concept of behaviorism. It grew largely out of the research of Carl Jung and is not as prevalent as the more popular cognitive and behavioral frameworks.

In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in the 1950’s near the village of Klimentovo in Bulgaria’s Varna province. This is the only discovery of a completely in vitro raised, artificially planted and cultivated settlement dating up to the middle of the 7th century BC. Klimentovo was the first sign that European farming had spread all over Europe.

However, it is generally recognized among archaeologists today that this site might not be the place where the first farmers appeared. As far as I know, all archaeologists agree on those 7th millennium BC sites, where in vitro raised, artificially planted and cultivated settlements were first discovered (the Klimentovo site being the only one among them where a complete and intact settlement has been discovered).

Although Ottoman madaris had a number of different branches of study, such as calligraphic sciences, oral sciences, and intellectual sciences, they primarily served one principal role: teaching children to read and write in Arabic. The Ottomans, like the Mameluks, did not believe that Islam would survive without the Qur'an's holy texts. By making the Qur'an an integral part of the Ottoman pedagogy, the madaris made it possible to spread the reading and writing of the Qur'an from the madaris into society at large. The education of Ottoman subjects focused on the reading of the Qur'an as the word, the oral transmission of Qur'anic knowledge, and the writing of texts based on the Qur'an, including the Qur'an itself. The madaris, however, took the education process one step further. They also attempted to develop the subject into an academic discipline. The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, a vast plain between the North and Middle Silesi. The southern part of the state lies on the river Saale and is known for its wine region. Other famous places include Lusatia, the biggest area of the German Democratic Republic, the old town of Erfurt and some well known lakes including Lake Müritz and Lake Constance.

Gera is the capital and the largest city of Thuringia. It is located on the river Ille, 80 km (50m) east-west of Erfurt. The state of Thuringia has over 200 towns. Some of them are quite small, having few inhabitants.

Throughout the 14th century, French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility. They ran into difficulties when attempting to assert their rule over the nobility, who were not easily subdued through economic means. As the Hundred Years’ War (1337–1453) intensified, so did the French monarchs’ failure to make inroads into the English dominions. This conflict was a struggle for international power between France and England and became entangled with and influenced the various regions of the continent, such as Italy, Germany, and, in the far south, Spain and Portugal. The French monarchy managed to secure its position in France and in the Holy Roman Empire, but it failed to conquer England. However, their failure to consolidate control over the smaller principalities of northern France forced them to engage in alliances with various rulers of principalities or, when necessary, to resort to military force.

The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea was formed, which was an equatorial landmass from which, in the final phase, Gondwana was divided. In the final 100 Ma of the Jurassic, the supercontinent assembled in the modern world, and there was increasing movement of organisms from Gondwana to the equatorial, now circum-Pacific, belt, resulting in the separation of Madagascar from Gondwana by the Indian plate and of Southeast Asia from Gondwana in the north. The Mesozoic lasted from the breakup of Pangaea to the end of the Cretaceous. The Tertiary was the last age of the Cenozoic.

The highest position in Islam, caliphate, was claimed by the sultans starting since Murad I, which was established as Ottoman Caliphate. The Ottomans also developed Islam as a state religion and transformed Sufi orders into an organized structure, and initiated reforms that led to the transformation of many of the social structures in the Middle-East and throughout the Islamic world. The first sultan to convert to Islam and to adopt the title of sultan was Murad I in the 14th century.

The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci, an early Illyrian tribe. The area was invaded during Ancient Roman times, and during that period, several cities developed in the region, including Segontia, Torella and Lugo. The province of Lugo was created by Pope Urban II in 1096. Its current borders were defined in the 13th century.

It is bordered by the provinces of Ourense, Pontevedra, Lugo and Córdoba.

The most important cities in Portugal are Lisbon, Coimbra, Porto, Braga and Póvoa de Varzim. The capital of Galicia is Santiago de Compostela.

Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals. They also have a greater heart rate to oxygen consumption ratio. The avian cardiovascular system is highly bradycardic, with blood pulsing from the left atrium through foramen ovale and the trabeculae of the ventricle at a rate of 150 times a minute. When it becomes oxygen-deprived, this blood is ejected into its oxygen-rich environment. As the avian heart is oxygen-dependent, heart function is critically important to survival; it should be noted that the avian heart is not a pump, but is rather an electrical generator. The avian heart therefore has a very low output and oxygen consumption. The avian heart is a modified sino ventricular muscle that is more appropriately compared to the human atrium or right atrium, but does not produce a stroke volume as in mammals. It

Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents explore their interests and values, define themselves, and discover what their life goals are (Cochran et al. 2009). They also become more sophisticated in thinking about how to manage their lives and emotions and experience greater feelings of agency (Cochran et al. 2009). The concept of identity development is derived from social psychology and was used in the 60s to describe the process of an individual deciding who he or she is.

While the concept of identity development has been extensively studied, it also receives much criticism and is still hotly debated. It has three main components. First, identity refers to how individuals understand their self. Second, the self-concepts individuals develop and sustain are the ways in which they explain themselves to themselves and others. Third, the process of making sense of new experiences is referred to as the process of becoming more

Athanasius recounts being a student, as well as being educated by the Martyrs of the Great (tenth) and last persecution of Christianity at Rome during the reign of Diocletian.

As Macarius was the Abbot of St. Pachomius Monastery the young Athanasius became a novice there. After Macarius’s death, he became Macarius’s subdeacon – and became increasingly involved in the affairs of the Church, especially during the time of the Great Persecution.

During the Persecution Saint Athanasius was arrested and spent some months behind bars before he was martyred

Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of self-acceptance, which emphasize being oneself despite societal expectations, egocentrism is concerned with being right—or at least superior—among oneself and one's peers ([@b2-arhw-20-1-6], [@b3-arhw-20-1-6]). Adolescents who seek social acceptance become concerned with the opinions of others, develop close friendships, and attempt to control the lives of their friends. Such people sometimes feel that others should conform to their opinion ([@b2-arhw-20-1-6]). Thus, these adolescents are egocentric in their relationships with others.

Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, who injected patients with epinephrine (now known as epinephrine injections) in a similar manner as was used in early studies of stress. Schachter's approach was to study the psychological and physiological components resulting from exposure to the situation prior to testing. For example, in studying whether children were more sensitive to teasing than adults, or less so, Schachter gave children a choice between the teasing of children and the teasing of adults in a social situation. Before testing, Schachter asked the children if they wanted the adult teasing or a similar degree of teasing from an older child. This was to check that adults were considered as more teasing than children. They were then tested either with the more experienced adult or children. Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these migrations resulted in at least two founders who survived. However, given the relatively recent history of the modern Ashkenazi population, two founders have not been the norm but were rather unusual events. With fewer than two founders, the analysis of Y chromosome haplotype variation is likely to reveal a significant role for founder effects in shaping the genetic variation found among Ashkenazim today. This finding seems to provide an explanation for many of the peculiar features of this population, and it may also have relevance for Y chromosome markers that were used to study the population history of the Middle East. In particular, it is interesting to note that in ancient Mesopotamia there were only two founders, and they seem to give rise to all the known male lineages living today.

Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid. The kidneys of birds, amphibians, and reptiles are relatively inefficient in terms of waste removal. Their primary function of reproduction takes priority over normal removal of waste, and the removal mechanisms are consequently overworked. By contrast, the kidneys of fishes and mammals play a major role in normal waste removal because of their efficiency in this function.

The metabolic demands on mammals are relatively modest, and waste is normally excreted as urine. Birds depend on an internal digestion of food and consequently are uricotelic in their metabolism. Fishes, like mammals, primarily depend on external digestion, which does not produce large amounts of undigested waste. This waste consists of dissolved nutrients, primarily urea (in most fish), which is eliminated by an elaborate system of renal tubules known as the kidneys. In all vertebrates

Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the wrestlers are in two separate lines with the two lines facing outward, and in alternating fashion, the participants make one pass between the lines and make contact with the opponent. The two wrestlers face each other, and the referee will signal when the contact had been made with the appropriate line. The other types of special match that have become popular include the "bullring" match, tag team match, and triple tag match.

Although the ladder match is widely considered to be a favorite among wrestling fans, the most difficult match wrestlers face in pro wrestling is a TLC match. This match is a one-on-one match between the two wrestlers, with various stipulations which include a pin fall, with or without a count out, with or without special circumstances, with or without the other wrestlers involved.

The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, signed on February 2, 1848, by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary Juan W. Alarcon, officially concluded the Mexican War. The treaty stipulated that the people of Mexico and former Mexican territories west of the Rio Grande would join the United States under the sovereignty of the former republic. The southern portion of the former Mexican states would become a new state of Coahuila y Tejas which, though initially unrecognized by the United States, quickly earned statehood in 1857.[1] The treaty also contained minor provisions concerning prisoners of war, and an article that the United States did not recognize. In return for Mexican territory, which included most of the areas that would become the state of Texas, the United States received a sizable amount of land from northern Mexico, including those areas that would later become states of Arizona, Nevada, New Mexico, Utah, and Wyoming.[2][3]

From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles being added together and, in some cases, subtracted from one another.

Since particle physics has changed (and still changes) from Feynman's time — for instance, a new particle has been discovered — his diagrams have changed shape, but they are still useful representations of how we believe particles interact. In a 2005 article in Scientific American, Feynman's daughter Emily explained that her father "had a very specific visual system for seeing the physics of things, an internal system, a neural network," and that this system enabled him to see "relationships, forces and dynamics," which he then expressed graphically. "He used his model-making tools to invent a diagram and tell an incredible story," Emily wrote.

At the 1912 Salon d'Automne an architectural installation was exhibited that quickly became known as Maison Cubiste (Cubist House), signed Raymond Duchamp-Villon.

The main structure consisted of a cube that was the home of five people in a space with three walls, two floors, five rooms, and other spaces. This cube was arranged as a family, with a mother, father, and four children (see sketch below).

The cube presented a revolutionary architectural and artistic concept from French Cubism.

The house was exhibited in the Salon de la Section d'Or at the 1913 Paris Salons, where Duchamp was among several artists asked to exhibit their work. Cubism had gained a great following in the salons and exhibitions, and the show was a hit.

Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept and worth.[@b35-asm-5-375] It involves evaluations which are the main determinants of how individuals feel about themselves, and as such are closely related to identity formation. Inadequate self-esteem can be viewed as an important factor which could inhibit the normal growth and maturation of children. In contrast, adequate self-esteem allows them to construct a good and strong sense of self.[@b36-asm-5-375] The main focus for the present study was to elucidate how children perceive themselves and to elicit information and views concerning the development of self-concept and self-esteem.

The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before the act was passed, which eventually evolved into the Montana State University.

Montana was a territory, and like all states in the Union, was created by and granted to the people of the United States. The federal government created Montana Territory after the Civil War. The new territory comprised both the northwestern and eastern portions of the present-day state. The northern part was designated as Washington Territory but was reorganized on Jan. 20, 1870, into its present form, Idaho Territory. The remainder, with the exception of the Indian Territory (Oklahoma), formed Montana Territory.

The territorial capital was established in Helena about a year after the territory was established.

On 20 June 1794, Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and he immediately resigned his seat, being succeeded by Sir Henry Creswicke. This resignation marked the only period of Burke's parliamentary career when he was not a member of parliament.

He soon left politics for the law and he became a justice of the King's Bench, retiring in 1801 as the senior judge. After Burke died on 20 February 1820, the bar of England and Wales was filled with his name. The following judges have been thought to have been his descendants: Horace Burke, John Burke, Arthur Burke and Walter Burke. A portrait in the National Portrait Gallery of Burke by his nephew, also Henry Burke, is inscribed "Ex tempore Henry Burke, de 1827 a 1854".

Several explanations have been offered for Yale’s representation in national elections since the end of the Vietnam War. Various sources note the spirit of campus activism in the 1970s, the perception of Yale University as a liberal bastion, and, more recently, the concern that Yale might seem too Republican and too conservative in view of the presidential candidacy of Mitt Romney (the GOP candidate) and the rise of Republican support in New Haven.

A broader context can be helpful. For too long the “Yale Vote” has been seen simply as a single entity—college students and alumni, voting as a bloc for the Democratic Party and then for one candidate in each presidential election. In fact, Yale has never presented a united voting bloc for one party. In some past presidential elections, a group of students or alumni supported a single candidate. Over time, however, the Yale vote split along many lines: class, gender, college, religion, racial and ethnic groups, and so forth.

Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute was designed to be an academic child-welfare agency: it could provide the research, information, and service necessary to help social agencies work with families. One of the first child-welfare agencies in the country, it became a model of collaboration between a research institute, concerned with identifying and remedying children's problems, and a child-welfare agency, concerned primarily with helping families.

The Institute's success has led some to ask whether child welfare programs as a whole could learn from its innovative use of scientific evaluation research. The answer is yes and no, depending on the particular program that is under consideration. As Macfarlane noted in a 1990 publication, "The Institute model is not the same for all programs, and the programs must decide how to define and implement the principles which form its core."

Usually a Presbyterian church will not have statues of saints, nor the ornate altar more typical of a Roman Catholic church. Instead, one will find a plain wooden box, containing a statue of the Lord, with only a few other items in the room. It may not look like much, but this is the room used to celebrate Holy Communion. This is because Holy Communion is simply a memorial of Jesus’ sacrificial death on the cross, and the Eucharist is not the same as the “real” Jesus.

Some years ago, I attended the annual meeting of a Presbyterian church that invited speakers who discussed the possibility of re-establishing a church’s communion service (the Lord’s Table). One of the speakers noted that there has long been a custom in some churches of having Holy Communion in an ornate style. He thought it was a sign of a “sick church,” and he recommended avoiding such practices.

From the 8th to the 10th century, three dynasties contested for control of northern India: the Gurjara Pratiharas of the North, the Pallava and the Guptas of the South.

The Pallava dynasty in particular, ruled briefly from the northern coast of Malayala or Malayissa between about 540 and 725, and again from 770 to 750. Both ruled extensively through much of the Pallava period. However, the Pallavas are most famous for two dynastic lines – the first was one of the first Buddhist monastic orders, headed by the great teacher Acumen, and the second were accomplished administrators and scholars who introduced Sanskrit to South India and were the inspiration for the Tamil country’s long-famous Tamil Sangam tradition at the time. Their first period of rule, however, was marred by repeated defeat by the rival Pratihara dynasty.

By far the largest military action in which the United States engaged during this era was the War of 1812. With Britain locked in a major war with the Netherlands, the British fleet arrived in July 1812 to enforce an increasingly unpopular order of British consul Edward Nicolls to American merchant vessels, which would not trade with Britain alone. This decision infuriated the merchants of Boston, whose trade with the United Kingdom had been decimated by British trade policy since the early 1790s. The British also imposed protectionist policies, tariffs on both imports and exports, which angered American politicians.

On August 19, the British fleet under the command of Admiral Sir Alexander Cochrane defeated the American naval forces at the Battle of Blackfish Creek, resulting in the Burning of Washington – one of the worst incidents of war in American history. The following August, U.S. diplomat Edward Everett, the new Secretary of State, publicly asked the British for a return to Washington, which Admiral Cochrane refused.

Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic. These mechanisms operate on multiple timescales and are strongly influenced by contextual experience as well as arousal, stress, hormones, and age.

First, it is important to discuss the neural substrates of memory. The hippocampus, specifically the CA1 region, is critical for long-term memories. While hippocampal engrams are formed, there is a delay of several minutes to hours before they are expressed, probably due to the fact that the CA1 region is critical for the formation of other memories. As with any neural circuitry, this system is flexible and can be influenced by experience and by hormones. There is much that is known about the neurobiology of the CA1 region, but we still do not know how long memory lasts in it, and many questions still remain that will likely be answered by advances made in molecular-genetics techniques

A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels (e.g., happiness);[1] and as emotional responses (e.g., joy, love, anger).[2] It also includes those who have experienced, or can access such emotions, and those who, however, have not.[1] Some conceptual approaches consider emotions to be a specific kind of feelings, which are associated with specific motives (i.e., love is a kind of feeling which motivates the pursuit of a lover).[3]

The concept of emotions is not widely agreed on in the social sciences: it has come into a range of distinct, sometimes conflicting, definitions (for example, see Emotion in anthropology, where this article was written; see also emotions).

Wallace's notes included a detailed account of five species of Melanesians who, he suggested, had been the first people ever to have "entered on the great field of competition and the battle of life." These "aborigines," as Wallace called them, had inhabited a series of islands in the archipelago and had been supplanted early in the Stone Age by people from Asia.

Darwin was intrigued. Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology), and natural science. These schools eventually became the universities, where the faculties of Arts and Sciences were created.

The faculties and schools of the universities were divided by the two dominant currents:

The so-called natural sciences, including the faculties of Medicine and Philosophy (including Logic, which had already been an important field since the Greek sophists in fifth century Greece), as well as Mathematics, Astronomy and Music.

The so-called liberal arts, such as Law, Letters (including Literature and Rhetoric), History, Geography and Rhetoric.

The history of university formation can be divided into three main time periods: the time period of the Middle Ages, the time of the Renaissance and the Age of Enlightenment, and the twentieth century university reform.

The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend bylaws. It needs to have some form of approval process for the board, and it may be the only way people know of a particular group. In the United States of America, all charitable organizations are nonprofit organizations, and it is nearly impossible to find a business that is not a 501(c)(3) organization.

• Membership organizations elect their board of directors. They have a certain amount of control over the organizational structure and processes.

Formal discipline is administered by congregation elders. There is usually a trial of all members at least two times in a calendar year. The proceedings are secret and are recorded online and sent by mail to the congregation.

The church has published the Manual of Instructions (Book of Discipline) which outlines the standards of conduct expected of members, and lays out sanctions and procedures for dealing with the conduct of others. Many cultures define the transition into adultlike sexuality by specific biological or social milestones in an adolescent's life. For example, menarche (the first menstruation at the onset of puberty), marriage, parenthood, and menopause (the last menstruation) are landmark developmental events for women in these cultures, representing a shift from dependence on her parents and the society to becoming an independent and self-sufficient individual. Similar milestones are associated with adolescence in males.
The menstrual cycle begins during early puberty and continues for the duration of fertility for most women, with ovulation and menstruation occurring in cycles lasting from 28 to 44 days. When adolescence progresses to adulthood, the ovulatory shift from menses to amenorrhea becomes evident. Amenorrheic women experience irregular bleeding intervals and are considered amenorrheic due to their lack of menstruation. Amenorrhea is a condition in which a woman does not menstruate regularly, or does not menstruate at all, resulting in infertility.

The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions", for instance, the Germanic migrations, such historical events were often far more complex than popular historical narrative suggests.

After the fall of the Western Roman Empire, which had ruled the people of the then known world for almost 400 years, a period of political instability, known as the Dark Ages (5th century and onward) began. Following this time, the Germanic peoples were pushed deep into the heart of Europe.

Prehistory to the end of the Western Roman Empire

Some of the differences in educational culture, such as the use of the gymnasium in secondary/high school, were shared with the US and Canada, while others, such as the use of French as the primary language of instruction, were uniquely different. The Yale Report of 1828 was a dogmatic defense of the Latin and Greek curriculum against critics who wanted more courses in modern languages, mathematics, and science.[1] It was penned by the Yale president, Joseph Dennie, who had succeeded John Norvell in the office in 1823.[2] Dennie and his colleagues defended their curriculum, which was widely felt in the 1830s to be outdated in light of new knowledge in the natural sciences, by presenting five reasons why their curriculum was better than what it was supplanted by. The first four rationales were: (1) the study of Latin and Greek in no way hindered the development of modern languages, (2) Greek and Latin are necessary to understanding the principal works of the greatest literature—the Bible and the classical authors—and to understanding the history of civilization, (3) Greek and Roman history and law are the best introduction to the science of political economy, and (4) a knowledge of Latin and Greek helps

Flexible or so-called "unbreakable" records made of unusual materials were introduced by a number of manufacturers at various times during the 78-79 period. The most common ones were made of metal-coated mylar, but also were of metal foil, coated foil and paper. The idea was to make a record "invincible" from all but a hammer, while being suitable to be played with a needle, and without the use of a turntable. These records were generally made at the factory to be a permanent part of the release run, but were not a common sight, and only a small number of copies of one particular record survived, though many of the records were issued in various variations, usually with a picture on the label as well as on the cover of the inner gatefold. Only a handful of these "invincible" records still exist today.

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A specimen is streaked on the growth medium, and a culture incubator is used to grow the specimen. The culture can be observed physically, typically via the color of the bacteria and other cells present in the specimen. A variety of tests have been developed to aid in diagnosis of disease using microbiological culture techniques. Examples include bacterial culture, fungal culture, and other more specialized assays. Culture is central to all aspects of microbiology.
An agar plate used for culturing microorganisms can be made from a gel-like substance, such as agar, that will support the growth of a microorganism. Various additives can be added to the gel, forming a culture medium, to enable a particular test result. While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned, Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture. Many local celebrations of the prelates of the area and the townsfolk themselves had their own customs and traditions. This became a time to let down social barriers; women and men mingled freely in public places during the festivities, engaging in carnal pleasures, which was condemned by the Church.

Carnival in Flanders and Zeeland started out on 1 January and 1 February. On the first Sunday of Lent, in a reversal of the Easter custom, all was made ready for the festivities to begin on 1 January. During the period before midnight mass, people would go to the main streets, where a pageant would be enacted. Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence in the home. Between the ages of 11 and 13, adolescence is marked by a dramatic heightening of assertiveness, an increase in interpersonal skills, and a growing interest in their own needs. During this critical period, the child takes an interest in making self-affirmations, and begins to develop more social awareness. Adolescence is also a period of increased sexual curiosity.

The social and sexual transformation that occurs during this stage of development may be marked by anxiety and insecurity. It is common for the adolescent to feel uncomfortable asking questions or making demands on the parent, and to demonstrate a need to feel cared and valued.

Homer refers to the "Hellenes" (/ˈhɛliːnz/) as a relatively small tribe settled in Thessalic Peninsula, Ancient Macedon, Central Greece and Western Macedonia, today in Greece. The term is also used by Homer's Greek contemporaries for Greeks generally.

The language of the Ionians in antiquity was not Greek, but a mixture of the Thracian and the Aeolian dialects, which had different levels of Hellenic influence. Under the Capetian dynasty France slowly began to expand its authority over the nobility, growing out of the Île-de-France to exert control over Brittany, Burgundy, Lorraine, Flanders, and the Low Countries. In the 14th century, King Philip II of France used the Hundred Years' War to expand French influence even farther, into Gascony, Normandy, and even into the Iberian Peninsula. These regions then formed the core of the vast empire that followed the French crown.

During the second half of the 14th century, the king was gradually replaced by councils of state (the Estates), which included representatives from all branches of the nobility and church hierarchy. From the 1360s, the nobility formed the Estates General, and from the 1380s they set aside two fixed sessions per year for legislative purposes only, at Easter and Michaelmas. The clergy joined them in early October, and the king joined the queen on Christmas Eve.

The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which introduced a new conceptual framework to explain the origins of different groups and cultures in Europe, Europe as a geographic entity, and Europeans as a human group. In the 17th century, the biological ideas associated with "race" were associated with the understanding that Europeans were descended from a common ancestor, the Biblical Adam. The concept expanded later to include the idea that a common humanity united people with different physical appearance and skin color, regardless of their social conditions and ancestry. There is a large body of published and unpublished data based on analysis of mitochondrial and nuclear DNA collected for both forensic purposes as well as for biological anthropologic needs. This paper summarizes some key features of mitochondrial and nuclear DNA analyses, and discusses the use of these tools in the study of genetic epidemiology in a variety of settings.

The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), to launch a satellite into orbit that could photograph, or even take control of, the United States. At the time of the race in the mid-1950s the Soviet Union and the United States had nuclear arsenals totalling between 60 and 70 bombs each. The result was the closest the world has seen to all-out nuclear war and has been compared to the Falklands war of the 21st century. For a list of all the launches that have ever taken place, see List of space launch systems: History of spaceflight.

The race was officially begun on 1 October 1957 with a launch of Soviet N-1 first stage to test technology of launching a satellite into orbit. Mary's complete sinlessness and concomitant exemption from any taint from the first moment of her existence was a doctrine familiar to Greek theologians of her day and age. The Hebrews, however, in whose writings Scripture is rooted, did not believe in the sinlessness of Adam's posterity.

The Hebrew term for "all flesh," Gen. 2:21, was applied indiscriminately to all people, irrespective of race or of their moral condition. The word "carnal" (used of sinful humanity at various passages) and "flesh" itself were used frequently to indicate the whole human race, as opposed to the righteous remnant who shall receive the adoption and exaltation after death. The term "flesh" (Greek, "Sarx"), therefore, was not limited to Adam's posterity, as it was in Hebrew.

There is usually an indication for a specific identification of an infectious agent only when such identification can aid in the treatment or prevention of the disease, or to aid in the diagnosis of the disease or its symptoms. The conventional method of identifying an infectious agent, such as the detection of the agent in the affected body fluid, usually relies upon the morphology of the agent. The detection of pathologic changes, such as the identification of specific antibodies produced by the host organism, is also used to identify infectious agents. These methods are not practical for the laboratory diagnosis of many infectious diseases and can not be used for the diagnosis of acute infections or as tests of the efficacy of treatment of a specific disease.
More recently, DNA probes specific for infectious agents have been developed which permit the laboratory diagnosis of infectious agents. Examples of this type of probe include the molecular beacon, enzyme amplified immunoassay, self-sustained sequence replication reactions, nucleic acid sequence based amplification reactions and branched DNA reactions.

The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806. In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign, Napoleon described the essential features of a “successful” offensive that would have been familiar to the French military and political leaders of that era. First, the campaign would consist of a series of small movements, all carefully concealed within larger operations, to “disrupt” the enemy’s rear area. The most likely approach into northern Italy would have been through the mountainous regions of Piedmont, where a series of thrusts could advance both west and north, encircling and then marching behind the enemy column. Second, the object of the “disruption” operations was to divert part of the Austrian army from its own planned operations and to force it into a series of costly defensive actions.

The Prince, a musical fanatic and lover of "virtuosity", expressed the wish that Haydn, his favourite composer, should be played as long and as badly as possible. Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a lifestyle or sets down a behavior pattern that excludes others from their life, or as a defensive mechanism. An inclusive boundary arises when the person adopts less restrictive behaviors, which can include relationships and choices, and this may include interactions with the person's extended social network.

Defining and clarifying boundaries is an integral part of many relationship issues as people try to deal with new situations and new people.

**Boundary ambiguity**

As a social exchange, boundary ambiguity occurs when there is a lack of clarity around appropriate limits. This ambiguity occurs when some forms of social behavior, such as the exchange of gifts, cause confusion around acceptable boundaries.

Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so. Exceptions to this include vitamins A, D, E and K that are essential in small amounts in the body's diet because the body can't make them and therefore must be obtained from external sources. Most vegetable oils used for cooking and other purposes are essential fatty acids. The human body can also "esterify" dietary fatty acids into esters that can be taken up and used.

Essential fatty acids can be classified by chemical structure, chain length and cis/trans isomerism. They have roles as biologically active components of membranes and as signaling molecules or precursors of signaling molecules and metabolic regulators. In Serbia, many streets and squares in the city of Niš in the Nišava valley are named after Tito in a number of cases. Several parts of the road linking Niš and the regional capital Novi Sad have named after him as well.

The "Tito City" are the areas with most street names after Tito within Niš. The first to be named after Tito (the street name and the building where the apartment complex was built during the Yugoslav economic boom between 1989 and 1993) was Šatovića in Niš.

Protestants also took the initiative in advocating for religious freedom. Freedom of conscience had high priority on the theological, philosophical, and political agendas since Luther the Reformation theologian, Calvin the Reformation theologian, as well the early Reformers argued that salvation was an individual act and not dependent upon external means of religious affiliation. In the 16th and 17th centuries, the Reformed Churches emphasized the "inner light" available to everyone regardless of the form their beliefs took, and not the necessity of belief in a particular religion in order to be a Christian. By the end of the Reformation, all the major denominations of Christianity agreed on essentials such as sola scriptura (scripture alone) and sola gratia (grace alone). The Protestant doctrine of grace, or the forgiveness of sins without the need of merit, was in conflict with the Roman Catholic doctrine of salvation by works. Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections included garlic, onions, and vinegar. Some of these remedies were reported to treat infections, even before there were any antibiotics that could be tested to see whether they had an antibacterial effect.[@CIT1] For example, people treated wounds using the ashes of an onion and vinegar mixture called "cataplasm." Antibacterial agents became the focus of much interest in medicine during the early 20th century, with the development of several generations of antibiotics, which reduced the need for medicinal folklore-based treatments.[@CIT2]

Mixed-use drugs were commonly used to treat respiratory infections.[@CIT3] During the 1950s, antibiotics such as penicillin and gentamicin were being administered via nasal drops. These medications often contained antifungal agents. However, the antifungal properties of

A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped when the ball touches the ground, as in soccer, but continues on until a new quarter of the game has been played; the half time interval starts with a 15-second signal from the sidelines and runs for 7 minutes before the teams take the field. The half time interval ends with a 3rd signal. This may occur when the game is not progressing and/or there are injury stoppages. During the 15 seconds, players and coaches may make some final comments between the play, but no major discussions can happen. The half time interval may be increased (to 8 minutes) if agreed upon by the referee and the teams (it could be an international or international club match) before the game.

The two squads must take the field in tandem. In a typical American football match the score will be 0–0 at the half time interval

By learning how to communicate with or in peer groups, adolescents are better able to achieve positive peer relationships in later years.

Communication within peer groups affects the extent to which adolescents' peer identities are formed and reinforced.

Communication within peer groups affects the extent to which adolescents' feelings about themselves are regulated--their emotions and their relationships to others.

Communication within peer groups affects the quality and extent of adolescents' peer networks.

Communication within peer groups affects the extent to which the social environment regulates learning by peer groups.

The "last days" era, or "the last days era", is the name applied to the era that began with the destruction of the Temple of Jerusalem in 70 AD, ending with the anticipated destruction of the present-day New Jerusalem, also known as Zion, in 2170 (the exact timing of this event, known as the "Great Disappointment", is not known but is usually projected to coincide with the 2nd coming of Jesus on Earth). They identify the Great Disappointment to be the start of the last era in Christian or Jewish history.
The "last days" era is viewed as being marked by seven consecutive world empires

The Empire was established in 1336 by Harihara I and his brother Bukka Raya I of Sangama Dynasty. The empire rose to prominence as a result of the decline of the Vijayanagara Empire. However, its existence was relatively short-lived between 1336 and 1346.

Sangama Empire was born with a dream of establishing the Hindu and Mahayana religious ideals on the Malabar Coast where it was founded by Harihara I. The Emperor ruled as the first ruler of the empire. Harihara's name derives from the Sanskrit words "har" meaning moon and "dānya" meaning fame. He became a legendary figure in the epic called the Ramayana and Mahabharata.

The dynasty that established their rule on the Malabar Coast was one of the few to have a dynasty in Hindu India with a name that reflects a certain Hindu ideal and aspiration. For example, they were named the Sinhalese in Ceylon

Hiberni (Ireland), Pictish (northern Britain) and Britons (southern Britain) tribes, all speaking Insular Celtic, inhabited the island before the arrival of the Romans. The Anglo-Saxons were the last of these to arrive and establish themselves in all these areas with the advent of the early Middle Ages, but the Romans introduced Christianity, and the Irish in particular were converted to Roman Catholicism at an early date. The first Gaelic kingdom, the Dál Riata kingdom, ruled most of western Scotland and Northern Ireland from around 300AD until the ninth century, when Irish influence was replaced by Norse influence. From the tenth century onwards the kingdoms of Ireland and the west of Britain were influenced by the Scandinavian Vikings. Libya returned to world prominence in 2011 with the overthrow of Muammar Gaddafi – a revolutionary change that prompted thousands of Libyans to leave the country in search of a safer life.

Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections in the brain strengthen, making memory more durable. People with epilepsy have a different sleep pattern, with increased latency to fall asleep. During sleep, they also have more frequent and shorter wake-ups (Wu et al., [@B74]; Riemann et al., [@B50]). Sleep-deprived animals and people have impaired memory. These types of memory impairment make their way back to school and work.

Nevertheless, Makdisi has asserted that the European university borrowed many of its features from the Islamic madrasa, including the concepts of a degree and specialization, the curriculum for a full-time program of study, and an examination system that would culminate in the promotion of scholars into official guilds.

Makdisi also argued that the Islamic sciences became more important following the destruction of the major libraries of Baghdad in the 7th century and continued to strengthen thanks to the patronage of the new capital cities.

He also made the case that while the Muslim reformers of the 17th century sought a secular, rational approach, the traditionalists continued to argue for a sacred Islam that remained focused on the authority of the hadith.

His work makes an important and, at times, surprising contribution to these debates. It makes a powerful case that while European universities did not borrow from the Islamic university, they did borrow from the Islamic madrasa.

The vast Seleucid Empire was, like Egypt, mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. The Greek population of the empire was, however, very substantial: "the number of cities of over a hundred thousand population is no less than four hundred and fifty". The major cities of the Seleucids included Antioch, Seleucia on the Tigris, Apamea on the Orontes, Alexandria, Emesa (also called Diospolis), Damascus, and Babylon.

The Seleucid kingdom included large parts of what is now Turkey, Syria, Iraq, Armenia, Iran, Lebanon, Israel, Palestine, Jordan, Israel, central and southern Arabia, Transcaucasia, and Egypt. “The roots of all our modern academic fields can be found within the pages of literature.” Literature in all its forms can be seen as an essential part of our culture. The ability to read and comprehend, and the freedom to do so, are central to society and to the democratic process. And yet how many people study literature? According to the results of a recent nationwide study, only about 1 percent of the population in the United States currently takes literature seriously enough to study it in school, with the majority of Americans reading for the sake of pleasure and entertainment. Yet literature contains important life lessons that can make any of us a better person; literature’s powerful truths of good and evil, of truth and error, of passion and restraint can serve as an entryway to understanding the human condition. Van Praag states that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses. Wang and Nyima argue that these were not only diplomatic missions, but rather were used to establish close ties that enabled Tibetans to access the imperial court.

The establishment of the Ming court's diplomatic mission to the Tibetan empire in 1552, when the Ming emperor Hongwu established the office of the vice-minister of the northwest frontier (陸部御史), was followed by the establishment of a series of diplomatic delegations between the two states. Tibetan records suggest that there at least was an exchange of two diplomatic delegations in the following years, and, indeed, an account by the Ming minister (司空) of the southern court on 5, 9, 14, and 26 July 1555 reports that the Lhasa embassy did travel to the Ming court. The first railways in Thuringia had been built in the 1840s and the network of main lines was finished around 1880. By 1920, many branch lines and industrial lines were built. They were nationalised and operated by Deutsche Reichsbahn. After World War II the new German state of Thuringia was created and the railways were privatised. Thuringia received the German Railway Award of 1994.

Rail travel through Thuringia is an important part of tourism in the state.

Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding" plumage.[3] However, birds can have various colours or tones of grey, brown, buffish grey, or white on their plumage. In some species, particularly in flightless species, the plumage is not useful, and these species have a vestigial or nonexistent plumage.[3]

Birds' bodies are also extremely malleable: during courtship, birds often form strong bonds that may be very difficult to sever, while during aggressive displays, birds may perform extraordinary feats of agility, like flipping over their opponent.[4]

Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements, particularly along the east coast of Ireland, the west coast of modern Scotland, Northern England, and the east coast of Northern Europe. Thereafter, the Norsemen travelled westward and the Viking Age spanned c. 840–1066. Scandinavian populations expanded and prospered (c. 850–950) as they dominated trade routes by sea and used their sea power to establish settlements on new land, particularly in Scandinavia, Iceland and North America. Their impact is seen in many regions of the world, where Scandinavian languages persist through the Old Norse language family.

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these free radicals are derived from molecular oxygen and are chemically reactive, highly unstable, and therefore very short lived. The end result is that free radicals have very short ranges of action. Free radicals exist as reactive species, such as superoxide, hydrogen peroxide, singlet oxygen, hydroxyl radical, and hydrogen radical. Oxygen free radicals are also generated in organisms as by-products of normal metabolism such as lipid peroxidation and xanthine oxidase.
It has been suggested free radicals play an important role in the aging process (Finkel, F. J., 1996. “Free-Radicals & Aging: The Case Against Free-Radical Theory” In: The Biology of Free Radicals: Molecular Strategies in Detoxification. T. Sies, ed. San Diego: Academic Press ). As a result,

Despite Martin Luther's harsh polemics against his Roman Catholic opponents over issues concerning Mary and the saints, theologians appear to agree that Luther adhered to the tradition of reverence for the Virgin Mary and the saints and that he recognized the efficacy of the Virgin Mary in salvation. Indeed, Luther has even been credited with reviving the concept of Mary as "Mediatrix of Grace" in the West.

In contrast, many Roman Catholic apologists, including Cardinal Ratzinger, have advanced a number of objections to the veneration of saints. The most famous of these defenses by Roman Catholic apologists of the doctrine of transubstantiation (a term meaning "change into blood") contends that the doctrine of transubstantiation cannot be understood as implying that Christ is present in the elements of the Eucharist that is consecrated by the Roman Catholic priest in a ritual of transubstantiation. In 1905, Lord Curzon split the large province of Bengal into a largely Hindu western half and "Eastern Bengal and Assam", a largely Muslim eastern half: the Bengal Renaissance began. 

The largest city is Kolkata, located in the eastern part of the former province, and the biggest industrial district is the Jamshedpur region in the southern part of Eastern Bengal. Kolkata still remains the capital of West Bengal.

Economic districts
The whole of Purba Medinipur district was part of the Hooghly Division, one of three divisions of Bengal for much of its history. The Hooghly, and ultimately the Calcutta Division, were economic regions. Bengal was the commercial and financial capital of India until British Raj.

The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical events can be reduced to (or even merely describe) statements about psychological events (and hence they were about psychology) and furthermore that the statements they describe are psychological ones.

This reduction of statements about physical events to

statements about psychological events, and

statements about psychological events to statements about physical events

was made possible by the success of physicalism in explaining such diverse phenomena as mind-brain identity theory, behaviourism and some theories of perception. Indeed the success of physicalism in accounting for physical events such as behaviour and perception led to the adoption of one of the central goals of theoretical

psychology: to explain "physical" phenomena by the use of psychological

concepts. This involved the re-interpretation of physical events in terms of

psychical states such as "perceiving"

The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by the indigenous Baiyue, while the river system of Hangzhou and Qiantang flowed through the eastern region, which would later be considered a vital area for the Qin dynasty and the rise of the Han dynasty.

The area of Zhejiang was originally densely populated. However, the climate of this region was similar to the climate of the southeastern area in China, and agriculture began to flourish only later. In the following centuries, this area remained relatively unpopulated, and its economy was mainly based on rice and agriculture. In the 9th century, however, the population of the region dramatically increased due to migration from southern China, such as Fujian and Jiangnan, as well as other Chinese people who had migrated to the Pearl River valley after it was opened to Chinese trade beginning in the 7th century.

Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be preyed upon by a human, raccoons may consume seeds and then be preyed on by a bird, and fish can catch crayfish and themselves be preyed upon by birds and even snakes and turtles.

In all of these cases the predator and prey interact very differently. For one thing, since fish eat fish, the prey and predator have similar senses - vision, hearing, and possibly smell too - although the predator doesn't need to hunt underwater because it can just fly above. The prey has many different senses to detect predators. Since blue jays often steal bread, it has a very strong sense of smell and sight and can even see color with its beak. It is thus able to avoid predators while it searches out food.

Because fish don't need to hunt, they can evolve to be much larger and smarter

The term "house music" is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. Clubbers to The Warehouse could purchase a piece of wax to record their favorite set. Those waxes were then sold in a booklet known as The Warehouse. Over time, the term "house music" was used to describe this genre of music.

In addition, house music is often credited as the genre that changed record production in the United States from analog to digital. As house music became more and more popular, DJs were recording their sets on cassette tapes, then later CDs, and eventually digital releases. As a result of this, the industry for musicians drastically changed as producers and engineers were able to create songs from the songs that DJs created with the equipment they used.

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. This revival was largely led by an elite of Greek noblemen. Following an economic crisis in 529-530, Constantine IV (r. 527–555) implemented a series of reforms intended to increase the productivity of labor, with the largest and most comprehensive being the Codex Theodosianus (also called "Codex E"). This codification, a collection of imperial edicts, represents a fundamental reform because it codified laws previously collected into a series of separate legal treatises that have gone down into the history books as the Corpus Juris Civilis (also known simply as the Code) by name. According to the Code, labor was divided into two classes: landless slaves who worked as paupers, such as agricultural laborers, and slaves that worked on rented property, such as house or craft workers. Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials. In Syria, fragments of mosaic flooring are known from the caliphates of Sulaymaniyya to Adhamyya. These examples usually have figurative designs intermixed with geometric figures.

Mosaic was also popular amongst Christian and Jewish visitors to the region. In the early 6th century a Roman mission arrived in Jerusalem and among their other findings brought back samples of the floor panels of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, now in the city of Istanbul. Mosaic became quite popular with the Christian population in Syria for much of its existence and it is estimated that during the 6th century the city of Antioch alone had a population of about 200,000 Christians, which placed it as the fourth most populous city in the Roman empire for over 1,000 years. Airports were typically founded by wealthy entrepreneurs who wished to set up their own aviation company, similar to how the early railways were established by entrepreneurs, or by the government to develop the country's infrastructure. With the establishment of air postal services and the need for air mail to be flown along a regularised route, in a small fleet of mostly biplane aircraft, the government gained the right to set up airports in each major city as part of a larger public works programme. By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike at the British Isles. Having made the decision to invade Britain, Napoleon wanted to use his new armies to attack the British army.

Napoleon began planning for the invasion of the British Isles in early 1805. During this time, his new army grew from about 60,000 to 125,000 men at the beginning of May 1805. He was especially concerned about the availability of manpower, particularly in Spain. It was becoming clear that large numbers of Spanish troops would be required to carry the war to the British Isles.

Napoleon also needed to reorganize the army to allow it to be deployed in new ways. As he planned for the British invasion, he wanted to build up his army by sending French troops to new armies. In the greater metropolitan area, 13% of the population live below the poverty line. According to a 2012 report submitted by GHMC to the World Bank, the Mumbai urban agglomeration ranks 10th (7th in India) in terms of the number of poor families. More than half of Mumbai's population lives in slums. For 2014, a study by the Maharashtra CMAT found that 20,735 people were affected by the slum regulation notification, which was a 2.1 percent increase from the previous year's tally.. An estimated 4,000,000 people reside in Mumbai slums, a number that is expected to top 5,000,000 by mid-2016.

One of the notable authors of esoteric interpretation prior to the 12th century is Sulami (d. 1021) without whose work the majority of very early writings on the subject would be lost. In his "The Book of the Perpetual Ascension" Sulami wrote "for the ascension is to be achieved in stages." This concept of stages of ascension has continued to be a part of esoteric interpretation through the ages and is an example of an esoteric belief system which is very similar to Christianity and Islam.

The concept of stages of ascension can be found not only in the writings of Sulami, but also in Hermetic literature (as will be discussed later in this page of this article), as well as within Sufi literature. All of these belief systems teach that it is possible for a man (or woman) to experience ascension progressively rather than all at once. It was the pub that first introduced the concept of the bar counter being used to serve the beer. Until that time beer establishments used to bring the beer to the table. Not only was this impractical in the modern era of bar space, it was a poor use of counter space.

But then the beer started flowing from a tap, onto a counter as a small part of a pub that was also a restaurant. The beer arrived at this same spot from a dispenser, so as one could always order another round. But the place this all occurred was the pub. The same pub.

This is how a bar started.

In response to attribution of recent climate change, the City of Melbourne, in 2002, set a target to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2020 and in this year announced the “C40” climate change action plan. Now, a C40 climate change council is to be formed, and a Climate Change Ambassadors Scheme funded annually by the council to train and place 100 people in high demand positions of responsibility in the city’s key organisations. The plan will be coordinated by the C40 Global Committee, whose secretariat has been established by the Melbourne City Council as part of a major strategy to protect the city from the impact of climate change, and to create a culture change around climate and energy. Melbourne is Australia’s seventh largest city and ranks in the top fifteen nationally in terms of carbon emissions. In 2010, it was the fifth most-populated city in Australia.
