Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian is a regional language of the Valencian Community region (Valencian Community, in Valencian: Estat de València, en català: Comunitat Valenciana). Valencia is the second largest municipality by population in the Valencian Community (2010), after Alacant, and is the capital of the Valencian Community  and the main city of Valencia Province. Historically, Valencia is considered the first capital of Castile.

Valencia is home to two UNESCO-recognized World Heritage Sites: The City of Arts and Sciences and the City of the Sea.

Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment at a revolution, which she had neither caused nor desired, is now obliged to become her own protector." Although he expressed concern, he thought only the guillotine, to be introduced soon, was to be feared. At his instigation, Parliament passed the Alien Act and the Declaratory Act. These declared the colonists' right to hold their property and gave legal weight to the notion that the colonies and parent country were separate political entities; the same principle was affirmed in the U.S. Constitution of 1787, a year before the first meeting of the French National Assembly. Burke's ideas, however, had a profound effect on the colonies; without them, they might have made other revolutions or continued to be "squeaky wheels" in a union of sovereign states.

Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old. The first evidence of human use of copper was on the Great Wall of China and archaeological excavations have shown evidence of use of copper by the Minoans in Greece, the Egyptians, the Romans and the Britons, amongst others. Copper is one of the most common minerals found in the Earth's crust. The discovery that gold and copper could be mined on the surface of the earth (known as surface mining) led to widespread use of both during the Middle Ages. Copper is usually found in the oxidation state of the +2 oxidation state, although much of it occurs in the +1 oxidation state as CuO. Copper oxide occurs as green or blue oxides[9] and sometimes also as blue arsenates.[10]

On 16 June 2014, the US Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled that broadband providers may reveal Internet users' browsing history during a lawsuit, holding in favor of the communications company Verizon, one of the broadband providers. The order reversed the district court's 2012 ruling, and held that when a plaintiff alleges harm from their ISP disclosing the history of activity, the defendant may present the history in court, without need for plaintiff's consent, provided that there is "another good and substantial reason." As examples, the court cited as being "another good and substantial reason" for admission of ISP history, instances of ISP retaliation against a plaintiff for filing suit, and "evidence to impeach [plaintiff] if he offers a different version of events." The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on oceanic vessels and overland at airports for example), the illegal pet trade, and in some cases even by scientists. But the rate of this invasion is unprecedented and there are many species involved. In fact, the sheer magnitude of invasions has made it one of the most difficult groups of problems facing conservationists today. The main purpose of this special issue of Oecologia was to provide researchers with an opportunity to share not only what has been learnt in dealing with the invasion of the most problematic species, but also what is known and what gaps remain to be filled before such efforts can be turned into comprehensive solutions for the conservation and future of mankind in its relationship with nature.

In the spring of 1800, Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy, aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula when he turned his attention elsewhere. Rather than risk his troops at these high altitudes, he sent them in in dribs and drabs from a wide crescent across the Alps, over several days and with great military deception.

But it was much too wide, with his forces strung out for many miles in each direction — leaving them vulnerable from any side. It was also just a single front. So Napoleon ordered some of the divisions to advance in parallel, forming a box around the others, while putting in a feint by the southern end. This would fool the Austrians into thinking he would assault the main body of their armies.

The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind was the work of Saint Thomas Aquinas; his major works were, in Latin: Summa Theologica, and in vernacular: Summa contra Gentiles, (Summing up against the heathens). These books covered all the principal matters of theology, philosophy, law, and metaphysics, and also included many of the most important subjects in medicine and biology as he could present them in a manner most intelligible to his readers.

These books were written primarily as aids to theologians—to train them how to think and how to write, especially concerning things that are properly a part of that field of study. Thus, their authors intended them to be used in universities. As regards their content, they were very different from what has come to be called modern science. Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current where the wire went through street crossties, and from there it went to an overhead collector. A "shoe horn" pole on the ground side of the wire directed current into the shoes of the tram wheels.
When the tram passed between the collector and third rail the current went into the shoes and into the wheels. The wheels then brought the current along the axle into the third rail again as current returns. 
When the tram started it picked up current from both sides, as it accelerated forward, then current from the third rail. 
At a stop the third rail was "shorted" or "grounded" so that the current went to "neutral".

In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the invention of the cylinder, Edison’s first commercial phonograph recorded only two songs in 1883, and no longer than an hour at a time.

It had always been hard to make records longer than five minutes. In 1883, only cylinder rotary machines could make records and they could only be two and a half minutes each. The technology needed to make longer recordings was far beyond Edison’s reach.

The fact that we take the idea of long-format recordings, of course, for granted today simply reflects how hard it had been to achieve in the past. Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion in 1807 that culminated with the Battle of Raslian, a costly defeat. In the wake of this defeat, France's eastern neighbors began to fear that Napoleonic domination of the continent would soon be their fate. A plan by Britain's Ambassador to the French government, Henry Dundas, to seize the Emperor and present his head to Tsar Alexander constituted the threat. Napoleonic invasion of Russia was thus not just motivated by a sense of grandeur and self-dramatization, nor was it a response to a long-standing military threat. Rather, the invasion's motivation included a desire by Napoleonic rulers in Paris to cement their claim to the throne of France by deposing the rightful occupant. In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and sustenance [1]. Energy is also a property of a body that is distinct from the body, and thus, energy is conserved. Energy is a physical phenomenon, and thus its amount is generally quantifiable (e.g., chemical energy is measured by the number of calories, Joules, or kilocalories). Energy always conserves. As an example, if you throw a ball up into the air, it will begin to fall back to earth, the energy has been conserved.
Energy is commonly described in terms of its potential; the ability of the system to perform work, whether the work is to lift, or to generate speed, or to release (as in combustion), heat, or some other use. Energy can be converted into any (or several) forms, such as heat, light, electrical potential, kinetic energy

Over the centuries they occupied territories from India through Pakistan and Afghanistan to Southern Iraq, where they eventually settled into what is now the current-day Iranian province of Khuzestan, and also in the province of Fars, north India and Pakistan. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by goldsmiths working from dies created by goldsmiths, jewelers, enamelists and goldbeaters, a skilled team that was in close contact with the royal workshops.

The first truly independent Carolingian goldsmith was the master goldbeater Pausa in the Merovingian court at Soissons in the mid-eighth century. By the ninth century, goldsmiths were creating a wide range of jewelry and enameling, but the most significant of the Carolingian art form was the crown. While the crown's style was developed in the West and became refined, the central element was produced in the workshops on the great Frankish monastic estates. Among his most famous pieces is a gilded reliquary that bears the face of Christ, a masterpiece of gold sculpture.

Following the unveiling of Windows 8, Microsoft faced criticism (particularly from free software supporters) for mandating that devices receiving its optional certification for Windows 8 have a set of specific hardware requirements. The requirements consist of a minimum amount of RAM, a "high-definition" screen with a resolution of 1366 or 1600 pixels wide by 768 or 854 pixels tall, and support for some specific interfaces and communication protocols.

This requirement has been criticized as being overly restrictive. The Windows blog, for example, stated that the requirements were "impossibly onerous", adding that many netbooks were already certified for use with Windows 8.[1]

In its original position statement regarding certification, Microsoft stated that it was trying to balance the concerns of compatibility with existing software with the desire have devices that are more secure by preventing or being resistant to bootkits.[2] The fact that the requirements apply only to Windows8 and not to any future versions of the operating system has also been criticized.

The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid, in spite of the numerous textual problems, constitute his magnum opus. At one time, the Aeneid aspired to perfection as poetry. Since it was completed at a time of crisis for the Roman Empire, this aspiration had a greater claim to truth than perhaps for any other Latin poem. Its structure was carefully worked out and its plan of action is entirely clear (Dent, I., 1:xxvii). From its first word, the poet proclaimeth the story of his own life, his experience of the vicissitudes of fortune and the struggle which he had encountered in the course of his military and diplomatic career. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury. It was to be done on Sputnik 1, a 184-pound satellite launched in January of that year on a three-stage rocket that could deliver an astronaut to orbit in 72 hours.

At the time of Sputnik 1, the Americans believed that they could place a man on another satellite in about three years, based on their work with Little Joe, a rocket designed by Bell Laboratories. But by 1960, the Kremlin had been preparing for the space race with unprecedented speed and secrecy, while the United States lagged behind. In response, President Eisenhower approved the Strategic Research in Space (SRC), to be directed by Brigadier General Robert R. Scott. Scott, already a decorated combat Army aviator, had been instrumental in developing, testing, and flying the first US missiles that could land in enemy territory and destroy them

In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12‐inch long‐playing (LP) records. To date \>100 LP records have been identified, the majority of which feature solo performances or duets. It was in the 1930s that the first \>50 LP recordings were made and these were usually made of solo performances on small labels mainly by jazz pianists or instrumental bands of the era. LP record production, as commercialized in the 1950s, and the emergence of the music industry were major factors in developing the new medium of recording. A significant advantage of these new compact discs was that they had sufficient playing time and could be used for longer‐term recording, as shown subsequently. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the Texas Revolution began when Sam Houston led an insurgency against Mexican rule. In December of that year, Sam Houston was sworn in as the new president of the Republic of Texas, a new republic, as it was not to last. After defeating Mexico the new republic was annexed by the United States and soon became part of the Confederacy after the Mexican–American War was over.

The modern state of Texas existed from the 1836 separation from Mexico until it became an independent nation in 1846, the first state to achieve independence. It was formed by a majority of the men born in the state, and those who had helped to defeat Santa Anna's forces at the Battle of San Jacinto in 1836. The state was incorporated under the 1845 Constitution of Texas, which was ratified after Sam Houston and his fellow leaders declared Texas to be independent of Mexico

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between the pope and the papal representative Charles of Anjou at the Council of Ravenna, just a few weeks after the interdict. A letter from Innocent to William I of Aquitaine, a relative of Charles of Anjou and claimant to the French throne, was intercepted. The letter warned William not to support Charles and to allow John to assume imperial power in France. Innocent asked William to "receive the prince of Aquitaine in your arms". William I of Aquitaine did as requested, although John used the letter as a pretext to confiscate John's lands in the county of Poitou and seize control of the county of Anjou. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has led to the formation of a large number of hybrid species worldwide. The occurrence of hybridisation between such close relatives is believed to be more common in nature than hitherto reported, but there are many cases where it can be documented and it is likely that there are many more cases from which the hybrids do not become known or reported. The scientific literature abounds with examples of the many hybrid species that have resulted from attempts to produce such species for the purpose of recreation or for experimental purposes. It is estimated worldwide that thousands of such species have resulted from these activities.
The deliberate or accidental hybridisation of closely related species is a difficult problem from both an animal and an economic standpoint and is therefore of considerable interest to the general public as well. From an economic standpoint, animals of the same species are generally of higher monetary value when hybridised. The possibility

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is simply a "belief in God only," whereas Thomas Jefferson called it "The only moral certainty." As for atheism, the idea that there is no god, it emerged largely as a consequence of philosophical naturalism during the 19th century.

There is little in the way of evidence for what Deists or atheists believed. As was the case in the 18th century, we do know what we don't believe. As for what we do believe, there's little disagreement: the main features of our modern religious beliefs are not contested.

Atheism and Deism

We can see some parallels between Deism and atheism. They are both beliefs in the existence of a god. However, atheists assert that there is no god. Deists, though, also assert there is no god.

Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.2 mph)), and -22 C was more common in St. John's than in any other Canadian city. It also experienced the fewest amount of rain events in major Canadian cities, with only 26 recorded - and 18 of those were snow events!

On a single day, the wind gust in major Canadian cities varied from -10.3 m/s during the morning rush-hour at 12:00 noon to -15.6 in the afternoon at 3:00 pm!

The daily wind gust in major Canadian cities can also vary by an extraordinary amount: as much as 100 m/s!

On a single day, the variation in daily wind gust speeds between Winnipeg and Montreal exceeded the variation seen in the same day's maximum and minimum air temperatures.

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Alps, the Jura Mountains and the Central Plateau.

The Alps cover a belt between the Rhone and the Ticino and stretch for about 500 km along the Italian and Austrian border. Their general range in elevation is between 1700 and 3270 m above sea level, with the highest mountain Monte Rosa reaching 6,516 m a.s.l.

The Jura Mountains lie in the western part of Switzerland. Their general elevation lies between 700 and 1750 m above sea level. The highest mountain is Matterhorn (Monte Rosa).

The Central Plateau, the largest and also the most populated, lies to the east of the Alps and the Jura Mountains. Its central extension reaches to about 500 km in length from north to south. Its elevation lies between 100 m and 400 m

The first four rationales were: (1) the study of Latin and Greek in no way hindered the development of modern languages, (2) Greek and Latin are necessary to understanding the principal works of the greatest literature—the Bible and the classical authors—and to understanding the history of civilization, (3) Greek and Roman history and law are the best introduction to the science of political economy, and (4) a knowledge of Latin and Greek helps.

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as short radicals can form. Most of these free radicals are derived from molecular oxygen and are chemically reactive, highly unstable, and therefore very short lived. The end result is that free it have very short ranges of action. Free radicals exist as reactive species, such as superoxide, hydrogen peroxide, singlet oxygen, hydroxyl radical, and hydrogen radical. Oxygen short radicals are also generated in organisms as by-products of normal metabolism such as lipid peroxidation and xanthine oxidase. This reduction of statements about physical events to statements about psychological events, and statements about psychological events to statements about physical events was made possible by the success of physicalism in explaining such diverse even as mind-brain identity theory, behaviourism and some theories of perception.
